Regina Elisabeta Bucharest 030018 Romania Several Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxides with different cobalt contents x between 7 and 50 at% with respect to cations, but with fixed 10 at% Ce and Mg/Al atomic ratio of 3, were obtained by the calcination of layered double hydroxide (LDH) precursors at 750 °C. The mixed oxide catalysts were characterized by XRD, nitrogen adsorption, DRIFT, DR-UV-Vis, SEM-EDX, including elemental mapping, XPS, H2-TPR and O2-TPO techniques. XRD analysis indicated the coexistence of Co3O4 crystallites with periclase-like and ceria phases, distributed homogeneously as shown by EDX measurements. The surface composition determined by XPS and the redox properties studied by H2-TPR and O2-TPO were shown to be key factors controlling the catalytic behavior of the investigated materials. Their catalytic performance was evaluated in the total oxidation of methane, used as a volatile organic compound (VOC) model molecule. Co(40)CeMgAlO mixed oxide showed the highest catalytic activity for methane combustion with a T50 of 528 °C, associated with its greatest Co/Ce surface atomic ratio and the best redox properties in the Co(x)CeMgAlO series. In addition, the influence of the contact time on the catalytic activity of the Co(40)CeMgAlO mixed oxide has been examined and its good stability was evidenced from combustion tests with prolonged time on stream. Nevertheless, the addition of water vapors to the reaction mixture induces textural and structural changes of the mixed oxide with negative consequences on its performance. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Layered double hydroxides Mixed oxides catalysts Cobalt Cerium Methane combustion VOC abatement Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Residual gaseous effluents from various industrial processes, but also from transportation and other economic activities contain volatile organic compounds (VOC), which are immense contributors to the air pollution as their continuous release into the environment can have harmful effects on human health and hazardous impacts on the atmosphere by increasing the levels of photochemical smog, formation of ground-level ozone and atmospheric ozone destruction [1–4]. The combustion of methane is of great importance for the production of energy, but not without environmental concerns, since it represents the most abundant component of natural gas. Indeed, it is a major hydrocarbon air pollutant with considerable effects on the global climate change, being the second largest contributor to the climate warming among the anthropogenic greenhouse gases (GHG) emitted at the global scale after carbon dioxide [5]. Moreover, methane has a global warming potential (GWP) 25 times higher over a 100-year time horizon compared to CO2, owing to its GHG ability to trap heat and its persistence in the atmosphere [6]. On the other hand, its high chemical inertness due to high dissociation energy of C-H bond (438 kJ mol−1) [7] renders methane as the most difficult organic molecule to oxidize and, hence, its catalytic combustion is often used as model reaction for finding active catalysts able to achieve VOC abatement. Low concentrations of VOC in residual flue gases from different industrial sectors cause their recovery to be economically disadvantageous, hence their destruction represents the only viable option to control their emissions [2,8]. The catalytic combustion is one of the most effective methods for VOC abatement, as it has some major advantages compared to the conventional flame combustion [9,10]. Indeed, the catalytic complete oxidation process takes place at lower temperature, leading thus to lower energy consumption and, also, to the inhibition of NOx formation, limiting, at the same time, the formation of partial oxidation products [11,12]. The most active catalysts for the combustion of VOC are divided in two main categories: supported noble metals and transition metal oxides [13–15]. Pd- or Pt-containing catalysts are known to be the most active catalytic materials for this process, however, they present several major drawbacks: they have high cost, they are easily deactivated at higher temperatures, due to their volatility and high sintering rates, and, in addition, by poisoning with sulfur compounds and water vapors under operating conditions [1,16,17]. Consequently, many efforts were directed in the last years towards the design of active catalysts for VOC combustion based on single and mixed transition-metal oxides, which are more stable and much cheaper, as viable alternatives to replace the noble metals in this process. Thus, numerous research papers published on this subject include several review papers and book chapters, which focused on catalytic combustion of VOC [2,10,18] and methane [15,19], or on different types of oxide catalysts, such as cobalt oxide [19–22], copper oxide [23,24], cerium oxide [25,26], ordered porous transition metal oxides [27], and LDH-derived mixed oxides [28]. Among the mixed oxide materials, those derived from LDH precursors have shown great potential in combustion processes, as they present high surface areas, high thermal stability and tunable redox and acid-base properties [29,30]. A major benefit of the LDH systems is the homogenous distribution of various combinations of MII and MIII metal cations in the brucite-like layers, which results in well-dispersed and stable mixed oxides after the calcination treatment. Controlled thermal decomposition of LDH precursors produced mesoporous MMgAlO mixed oxide catalysts (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ag and Pd), with promising activity for the total oxidation of short-chain hydrocarbons, the Co- and Cu-containing systems being the most active in methane combustion [31,32]. Further studies on a series of lanthanide-containing LDH-derived mixed oxides catalysts, LnMgAlO (Ln = Ce, Sm, Dy and Yb), showed that the Ce-based catalyst gave the highest activity in methane total oxidation with an optimum Ce content of ca. 10 at% [33]. Also, the cobalt spinel oxide, Co3O4, was shown to exhibit high activity for the lean methane catalytic combustion, thanks to the presence of variable valence states (Co2+/Co3+) and its lower bonding energy of Co-O bonds [34–36]. Therefore, with the aim to combine the advantages of mixed oxides prepared from LDH precursors with the high activity of Co-based systems in methane combustion together with an expected Co-Ce synergistic effect [37], the present work investigates a series of new LDH-derived CoCeMgAl mixed oxides with 10 at% Ce and different Co content ranging from 7 to 50 at% (with respect to cations). 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts preparation A series of six Co(x)CeMgAl LDH precursors with the cobalt content x ranging from 7 to 50 at% with respect to cations, but with fixed 10 at% Ce and Mg/Al atomic ratio of 3, were prepared by coprecipitation under ambient atmosphere. In a typical procedure, a mixed salts solution (400 mL) of Mg(NO3)2·6 H2O, Al(NO3)3·9 H2O, Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O and Co(NO3)2·6 H2O and an alkaline solution of NaOH (2 M) were simultaneously added dropwise into a beaker containing 200 mL deionized water at room temperature with controlled rate in order to maintain the pH close to 10. After complete precipitation, the slurry was aged at 80 °C overnight under vigorous stirring. The precipitate was then separated by centrifugation, thoroughly washed with deionized water and finally dried overnight at 80 °C. The Co(x)CeMgAlO catalysts, with x = 7, 14, 21, 30, 40 and 50 at%, respectively, were obtained by calcination of their corresponding LDH precursors in air at 750 °C for 8 h. 2.2 Catalysts characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of both precursors and mixed oxides were acquired with a 9 kW Rigaku SmartLab diﬀraction system with rotating anode, equipped with a Cu-Kα1 radiation source with the wavelength, λ = 1.5406 Å, operated at 40 kV and 75 mA. They were recorded over the 5–70° 2θ angular range at a scanning rate of 3° min−1 and with a 0.01° step width. Crystalline phases were identified using standard JCPDS files. The mean crystallite size of the oxide materials was calculated by using the Scherrer equation: D = K λ β cos θ where D is the mean crystallite size, K is the shape factor, taken as 0.93, λ is the Cu Kα1 X-ray wavelength, θ is the Bragg diffraction angle and β is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the diffraction line, in radians. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) together with X-ray energy dispersion analysis (EDX) were used to monitor the morphology and chemical composition of the mixed oxides. Additionally, elemental mapping was carried out in order to evidence the uniform distribution of the different elements within the mixed oxide. SEM/EDX examination was performed using a field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM), FEI-NOVA NanoSEM 630 equipped with an EDX module, operated at an accelerating voltage of 20 kV. Four different areas were analyzed on each sample, the reported composition being the average of these measurements. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to determine the chemical state of the elements on the catalyst surface with a SPECS spectrometer equipped with a PHOIBOS 150 analyzer using a monochromatic Al Kα radiation source (1486.7 eV). The acquisition was operated at a pass energy of 20 eV for the individual spectral lines and 50 eV for the extended spectra. The analysis of the spectra has been performed with the Spectral Data Processor v2.3 software using Voigt functions and usual sensitivity factors. The textural characterization was performed using the conventional nitrogen adsorption/desorption method at − 196 °C, with a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 automatic equipment. The surface areas were calculated using the BET method in the relative pressure, P/P0, region 0.065–0.2, while the average pore sizes were determined using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method from the desorption branch of the isotherms. The total pore volume was estimated from the amount adsorbed at the relative pressure of 0.99. Prior to nitrogen adsorption, the oxide samples were degassed at 250 °C for 6 h. DRIFT spectra were obtained after an accumulation of 400 scans in the 400–4000 cm−1 domain with a JASCO FT/IR-4700 LE spectrometer (Jasco, Tokyo, Japan). The data collected were converted in transmittance units and then used for the plots. Diffuse reflectance electronic spectra were recorded in the range 200–1500 nm with a Jasco V 670 spectrophotometer and using Spectralon as a standard. The obtained reflectance spectra were converted into the dependencies of Kubelka-Munk function on the absorption energy. The redox properties of the catalysts were studied by temperature programmed reduction under hydrogen (H2-TPR) and oxygen temperature-programmed oxidation (O2-TPO). Experiments were performed using a TPR/TPO Chembet 3000-Quantachrome apparatus equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 80 mg of calcined mixed oxide was placed in a quartz tube. Then, a 5 % H2 in Ar flow (70 mL min−1) was passed over the sample, which was heated from room temperature to 700 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1. The consumption of H2 was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) operating at 150 mA. After cooling down to room temperature, the reduced samples were re-oxidized by a gas mixture of 5 % O2 in He (70 mL min−1), using a similar temperature program as for the H2-TPR (10 °C min−1 heating rate until 800 °C). 2.3 Catalytic test The catalytic tests for the methane combustion over the mixed oxide catalysts were carried out in a fixed bed quartz tube down-flow reactor at atmospheric pressure. If not otherwise specified, a mixture of CH4 and air containing 1 vol% methane was passed through 1 cm3 (ca. 0.8 g) catalyst bed with a total flow rate of 267 mL min−1 corresponding to a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 16,000 h−1. Before testing, the catalyst was pre-treated for 30 min in a stream of air at 600 °C for cleaning its surface. Activity measurements were performed by increasing the reaction temperature from 400° to 730°C at regular intervals. Catalytic tests in humid conditions were performed by introducing, with a peristaltic pump, deionized water (0.14 mL min−1) in the reaction mixture containing 1 vol% methane in air fed into the reactor with a flow rate of 267 mL min−1, corresponding to a water vapor content of ca. 40 vol%. The reactants and product gases were analyzed online by a Clarus 500 Gas-Chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector, using two packed columns in series (6 ft Hayesep and 10 ft molecular sieve 5 Å). The catalysts activity was characterized by T10, T50 and T90 representing the temperatures of methane conversions of 10 %, 50 % and 90 %, respectively. The conversion was calculated as the amount of methane transformed in the reaction divided by the amount that was fed to the reactor by using the following formula: Conversion % = C C H 4 , in − C C H 4 , out C C H 4 , in × 100 where C CH4,in and C CH4,out represent the methane concentration (v/v) in the feed and effluent gases, respectively. Complete selectivity to CO2 and H2O was always observed. The carbon balance was calculated based on the following equation: C C H 4 , in = C C H 4 , out + C C O 2 , out where C CO2,out is the concentration of carbon dioxide (v/v) in the effluent gas. It was satisfactory in all runs to within ± 2 %. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization The as-prepared LDH precursors displayed similar XRD patterns with diffraction lines ascribed to poorly crystallized LDH (JCPDS 37–0630) and boehmite AlOOH (JCPDS 83–2384) phases ( Fig. 1). No other diffraction lines corresponding to cobalt- or cerium-containing additional phases were observed in the X-ray diffractograms, suggesting that the transition-metal ions are well dispersed in the precursor samples. After the calcination process, Mg(Al)O mixed oxide phase with a periclase-like structure (JCPDS-ICDD 4–0829) and CeO2 fluorite phase (JCPDS 75–0076) were identified in all the obtained Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxide materials ( Fig. 2). The characteristic diffraction line corresponding to the Co3O4 spinel phase (JCPDS 42–1467) at 36.62° was observable even for the Co(7)CeMgAlO system, as a low intensity line. However, as the Co content in the mixed oxides was raised, this line increased in intensity, in addition to the appearance of other diffraction lines, ascribed to the Co3O4 phase. The XRD pattern of the cobalt oxide started to be well-defined after reaching a considerable Co content in the mixed oxides, i.e., higher than 21 at%. The mean crystallite size of the different oxide phases was calculated using the Scherrer equation. For cobalt oxide, it was estimated to be around 13–14 nm for all the samples with x > 21, while for the ceria phase, it varies within a narrow range, i.e., 7.5–9 nm ( Table 1), except for the Co-free CeMgAlO sample, for which it is lower (4.7 nm). The crystallite size of the periclase-like phase is ranging from 6.5 to 14 nm irrespective of the Co content (Table 1), the lowest value corresponding to the Co-free CeMgAlO sample. On the other hand, the periclase lattice parameter increased with the Co content, suggesting a structural modification. Taking into account the difference in ionic radius of Al3+ (0.53 Å), on one hand, and Co2+ (0.7 Å) and Co3+ (0.6 Å), on the other hand, the incorporation of cobalt ions into the periclase-like lattice, containing mostly Mg2+ ions (0.72 Å), substituting both magnesium and smaller aluminum ions, takes place as the Co content is increased, thus resulting in the expansion of the lattice. The extent of Co insertion in the periclase lattice is limited as evidenced by the XRD patterns that display the emergence of the most intense diffraction line corresponding to the Co3O4 spinel phase in the catalyst with the lowest Co content, suggesting that the cobalt ions are not entirely dispersed in the periclase phase, but also form a separate phase of cobalt oxide, even at the lowest Co content in the series. This behavior emphasizes the low solubility of Co ions in periclase. Therefore, in the Co(x)CeMgAlO catalysts, Co3O4 crystallites coexist with ceria particles and a Co-doped Mg(Al)O periclase-like phase. The XRD patterns of the materials showed unchanged reflections after the catalytic tests compared to the initial mixed oxides, as depicted in Fig. S1 for the Co(x)CeMgAlO samples with x = 21 and 40, respectively. The DRIFT spectra of all the mixed oxide samples displayed two broad and intense bands with peaks at around 3600 and 1600 cm−1, which can be ascribed to the vibration modes of the O-H bond, from the water molecules or hydroxyl groups bound to the cations (Fig. S2a) [38]. The close-up view over the 1200–400 cm−1 region evidenced the presence of transition and rare earth metal ions by revealing multiple bands that correspond to the M-O vibrations, as follows: the bands at 649 cm−1 and 541 cm−1 belong to the tetra-coordinated Co2+ and octahedral Co3+, respectively, together with a band at 456 cm−1 for the Co-O stretching mode, and two additional bands at 488 cm−1 and 416 cm−1, which can be attributed to the Ce-OH2 wagging vibration and Ce-O stretching, respectively (Fig. S2b) [38,39]. In the electronic spectra of the Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxides (Fig. S3), charge transfer bands (CT) are observed in the UV region, while in the Vis-NIR region appear bands characteristic for d-d transitions of cobalt (II) ion. In the UV region, the two absorption bands with maxima at around 300 and 430 nm can be assigned to the charge transfers between O2- and Co2+ or Co3+ ions, respectively [40]. Moreover, an interesting aspect about the d-d bands is that their intensity increases and the absorption maxima shift to higher wavelengths (lower energies) as the cobalt (II) content increases. Both characteristics can be explained considering two types of stereochemistry for cobalt (II) ions. Thus, for Co(7) sample, the d-d transitions are in agreement with a tetragonally distorted octahedral (Oh) stereochemistry [41]. The intensity of the bands is low due to Laporte interdiction rule [42]. As the cobalt ion content increases, a new peak appears at about 1520 nm, which is characteristic of tetrahedral (Td) stereochemistry. Also, the band located at around 600 nm in the spectrum of Co(7) sample shifts to higher wavelengths for the other mixed oxides and becomes more and more intense with increasing the Co content. This is in accord with the presence of cobalt ions in a tetrahedral stereochemistry. Since for tetrahedral stereochemistry the d-d transitions are Laporte allowed, the intensity of these bands become similar with that of CT bands for samples with higher content of cobalt ions. The assignments of all the bands observed in the electronic spectra of the Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxides are tabulated in Table S1. The textural properties, including the specific surface area, the pore volume and the pore size of the Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxides are listed in Table 1, with their corresponding adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions depicted in Figs. S4 and S5, respectively. The specific surface area of the Co-containing samples decreases as the Co content increased, from 127.2 m2 g−1 for Co(7)CeMgAlO to 80.4 m2 g−1 for Co(50)CeMgAlO. This can be explained by the apparition of larger Co3O4 crystallites in the samples with Co loading higher than 21 at% and, at the same time, by an increase in the crystallite size of the periclase-like phase, which acts as support matrix for the catalyst. The mixed oxides display type IV isotherms according to the IUPAC classification, with H2b-type hysteresis loops characteristic of mesoporous materials with complex pore structures (Fig. S4) [43]. The pore size distributions of the solids (Fig. S5), obtained from the desorption branch of the isotherms, indicate bimodal pore structures extending from 3 to ca. 20 nm, with well-defined maxima at 3.8–3.9 nm and within the range 7.6–19.1 nm, respectively, for Co(x)CeMgAlO samples with low Co content (x ≤ 21). The CeMgAlO and Co(x)CeMgAlO samples with high Co content (x > 21) show larger unimodal pore size distributions within the range from 3 to ca. 30 nm, with maxima at 8.9 nm for the former and in the range from 17.5 to 24.1 nm for the latter. The pore volume of the Co-containing mixed oxides increases with increasing the Co content and passes through a maximum of 0.59 cm3 g−1 for Co(30)CeMgAlO sample (Table 1), in line with their pore size evolution. The cationic composition of the LDH-derived mixed oxides has been estimated by EDX spectroscopy, the results obtained being presented in Table 2. It can be observed that the Co and Ce contents are in good agreement with the intended theoretical values, except for Co(14)CeMgAlO mixed oxide, which contains lower Co and Ce amounts. In addition, the Mg/Al atomic ratio was quite close to the fixed value of 3 in the synthesis solution, while the Co/Ce atomic ratio was slightly higher than the fixed value for all the oxide samples. Notably, for each sample, EDX analysis was performed in different areas, obtaining similar cationic content, which suggests a homogeneous distribution of the elements within the mixed oxides achieved during the preparation of the LDH precursors. This has been confirmed by the SEM mapping images for the Co(x)CeMgAlO samples with x = 7, 21, 40 and 50, presented in Fig. S6. The SEM images of the Co(x)CeMgAlO samples are shown in Figs. S7 and S8. It can be observed that the catalysts have the aspect of aggregates with micrometric sizes, comprised of nanometric crystallites, as expected from the Scherrer crystallite size. Interestingly, when the Co content is reaching 21 at%, fluffy smaller particles start to become more frequent, covering larger micrometric aggregates (Fig. S7). As inferred from the XRD patterns, the diffraction lines of Co3O4 spinel phase started to be well defined from the Co(21)CeMgAlO sample with the increase in Co content, and, hence, the appearance of these additional particles can be ascribed to the formation of a separate phase of cobalt oxide in significant amounts to be detected in XRD and SEM measurements. Moreover, in the samples with the highest Co content (x = 40 and 50), as Co3O4 is the main component in the mixed oxide, the agglomeration of these spinel particles taking the form of a film, covering the surface of the aggregates is evidenced (Fig. S8). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy has been used to identify the oxidation states of the different elements existing on the surface of the Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxides. All the expected elements, i.e., Co, Ce, Mg, Al, O and C are present on their surface ( Table 3). The O 1 s core level XPS spectra ( Fig. 3a) indicated for all the samples a peak which could be mainly deconvoluted into two components, corresponding to the lattice oxygen in oxide (ca. 530 eV) and oxygen in the lateral structure (ca. 532 eV), respectively [44]. The oxygen in the lateral structure appears in the form of hydroxyl or carbonate species [45], or as subsurface oxygen ions with particular coordination and lower electron density compared to the lattice oxygen [44]. Based on the origin and chemical composition of these oxides, the hydroxylation and carbonatation of their surface likely represent an important contribution to the component at 532 eV. At the same time, the subsurface oxygen ions probably located at the interface of the different crystalline phases have an additional contribution to the XPS peak component at 532 eV. Meanwhile, the C 1 s core level (Fig. 3b) shows two main peaks, attributed to the presence of adventitious hydrocarbon species (284.8 eV) and carbon in carbonate (ca. 289.2 eV) [45]. These results are in accordance with the DRIFT analysis and validate the pretreatment of the catalysts in the reactor under air at 600 °C before each activity test in order to clean their surface [33]. The XPS spectra of Co 2p core level of the Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxides are displayed in Fig. 4a and the surface concentrations of cobalt together with Co(III)/Co atomic ratios are included in Table 3. As depicted in Fig. 4a, the Co 2p spectra present two major peaks, corresponding to Co 2p3/2 (ca. 780 eV) and Co 2p1/2 (ca. 796 eV) with a spin-orbit splitting of around 16 eV, emphasizing the existence of both Co2+ and Co3+ species [35,46]. The satellite peak at about 787 eV is also an indication for the presence of Co2+ ions [47,48]. In order to determine the cobalt surface composition, the Co 2p3/2 and its satellite peaks were deconvoluted into four contributions: Co3+ in octahedral coordination (780.1 eV), Co2+ in tetrahedral coordination (781.4 eV) and the satellite peaks (783.3 eV; 787.8 eV) [35]. The surface Co(III)/Co atomic ratio was calculated from the areas of the Co2+ and Co3+ components from the Co 2p3/2 peak deconvolution, using the following equation: Co III Co = B A + B where A is the percentage of the peak area for the Co2+ component and B is the percentage of the peak area for the Co3+ component, obtained from Co 2p3/2 deconvolution. As the Co loading increased in the samples, the Co3+ content found at the oxide surface increased (Table 3), suggesting their high potential in the methane combustion process [36]. Notably, compared to the data obtained by EDX (Table 2), the surface Co content is significantly lower than that of the bulk in the Co(x)CeMgAlO samples with x ≥ 21. The photoelectron profile of Ce 3d region for all the Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxides are presented in Fig. 4b. Pure Ce(IV) oxide should present six peaks (three pairs of spin-orbit doublets) in the XPS spectrum, which are labeled in order of decreasing energy as U’’’, U’’ and U (corresponding to the Ce 3d3/2 level) and V’’’, V’’ and V (corresponding to the Ce 3d5/2 level) [49]. On the other hand, the XPS spectrum of the cerium (III) oxide presents four peaks (two pairs of spin-orbit doublets), which are labeled as U′, U0 (for the Ce 3d3/2 level) and V′, V0 (for the Ce 3d5/2 level) [49]. The XPS spectra of the Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxides is represented as a superposition of all these ten features originating from both Ce(III) and Ce(IV) species found on the oxide surface, as indicated in Fig. 4b. The values of the characteristic binding energies of these peaks in the Ce 3d core level XPS spectra were ascertained from Ref. [50]. Taking into account that the U’’’ peak is absent from the Ce 3d spectrum of pure Ce(III) oxide and, hence, exclusively corresponds to Ce(IV), it can be used in the quantitative determination of the amount of the latter [51]. Therefore, considering that, for pure Ce(IV) oxide, the U’’’ peak represents ca. 14 % of total integral intensity [51], the percentage of surface Ce(IV) was calculated using the following equation: % Ce IV = % U ′′′ 14 × 100 where %U’’’ represents the percentage of U”’ peak area with respect to the total Ce 3d area. The Ce(IV)/Ce surface atomic ratio (Table 3) was found to be higher than 0.8 for all the samples, evidencing the presence of low amounts of surface Ce(III), which vary irrespective to the Co content. Interestingly, the surface Ce content is slightly higher than that of the bulk (Table 2) for all the Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxides, showing an enrichment of Ce species at the surface level. Moreover, the Co/Ce surface atomic ratio has increased with the Co loading, and reached a maximum for the Co(40)CeMgAlO sample (Table 3). The XPS spectra of the Al 2p and Mg 2p in the Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxide series are illustrated in Figs. S9 and S10, respectively. Fig. S10 also presents the Auger Mg KLL spectra. The relative peak positions of both Al and Mg are stable along the catalyst series and are ascribed to Al3+ and Mg2+ found in their corresponding oxides. This was confirmed for Mg by calculating the modified Auger parameter (m-AP) using the following formula: m-AP = BE Mg2p + KE MgKLL where BE Mg2p is the binding energy of Mg 2p and KE MgKLL , the kinetic energy of the MgKLL peak. The calculated m-AP values (Table S2) are specific for MgO [52] in all the mixed oxide samples. The Mg/Al surface atomic ratio (Table 3) is lower than the bulk ratio for all the samples, indicating the Al enrichment of the surface. H2-TPR measurements were carried out to investigate the reducibility of the Co(x)CeMgAlO catalysts. The TPR profiles are depicted in Fig. 5, along with their corresponding H2 consumptions in Table 4. The CeMgAlO support presents in its reduction profile three asymmetric reduction peaks with two of them below and one above 500 °C. They correspond to ceria particles having different reducibility, depending on their size and interaction with the periclase phase [32]. Thus, in the low-temperature region (below 500 °C), the H2 consumption is due to the highly reducible ceria particles dispersed on the surface of the Mg(Al)O mixed oxide support, along with the ceria particles interacting with the support and Ce4+ species included in the periclase phase at the surface level, showing maxima at temperatures of 326 and 450 °C. For the high-temperature region (above 500 °C), the less reducible and large ceria particles dispersed in the Mg(Al)O matrix, having strong interactions with the support, are responsible for the respective reduction peak with maximum at 656 °C. On the other hand, all the Co-containing mixed oxides also showed three reduction peaks, except of the Co(7)CeMgAlO sample. The latter displayed a reduction profile with two large peaks ascribed to the reduction of surface highly dispersed cobalt species from the Co3O4 crystallites or other Co-doped phases, i.e., periclase and ceria, in the temperature range of 200–550 °C with maxima at 342 and 455 °C, corresponding to the stepwise reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ and Co2+ to Co0, respectively [35,36]. As well, the surface Ce4+ species from the cerium oxide can participate in a reduction event in this temperature range, as ceria phase can be reduced by atomic hydrogen formed by the dissociation of dihydrogen on the surface metallic cobalt particles [24]. At the same time, as the Co content increases in the series, the first reduction peak corresponding to the reduction process of the superficial Co and Ce species appears at lower temperatures (e.g., 310 and 253 °C for Co(14) and Co(40) samples, respectively), indicating an increase in reactivity of the catalysts inasmuch as Co species are more prevalent at the surface. The second reduction peak, with maxima in the 450–500 °C temperature region, is due to cobalt oxide particles interacting more strongly with the support [53] The high-temperature reduction peak in the region of 550–650 °C can be attributed to the reduction of Co2+ ions to Co0 from less reducible forms such as CoAl2O4 or Co2AlO4 [54,55]. The contribution of less reducible large ceria particles to this high-temperature reduction peak cannot be excluded, showing as well a decrease in the reduction temperature compared to the CeMgAlO sample (e.g., 656 °C for CeMgAlO compared to 603 °C for Co(21)CeMgAlO). The hydrogen consumption of the Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxides was considerably higher compared to that of the CeMgAlO support and revealed a continuous increase in H2 uptake as the Co loading was raised in the oxide series (Table 4). It can be observed that the H2 consumption in the low temperature region (250–500 °C) is higher than that at temperatures above 550 °C, indicating a majority of highly reducible cobalt species in the samples over the less reducible bulk Co ions, strongly bound to the support phase. However, the total experimental H2 consumption is significantly lower than the calculated H2 amount, required for the Co reduction, which was quantified based on the oxide composition and assuming the total reduction of all cobalt species. These results suggest that the reduction process mostly occurred at the surface and sub-surface level of the catalysts, where the highly reducible species are located. On the other hand, the presence of bulk Co species which are less reducible can explain to some extent the lower experimental H2 uptake compared to the calculated amount. Notably, even though the presence of ceria in the sample was found to limit the formation of CoAl2O4 [36], the respective aluminate phase can act as a barrier, preventing the access of the other Co species for reduction with H2, thereby resulting the low experimental hydrogen amount. After the reduction of the mixed oxides in the H2-TPR measurements, O2-TPO experiments were carried out to investigate their reoxidation capacity. The TPO profiles revealed for all the samples two broad regions, with maxima at ca. 300 and 650 °C, respectively, as depicted in Fig. 6. The low-temperature peak can be attributed to the oxidation of the metallic cobalt species at the surface level or close to the surface, which were firstly reduced in TPR, along with the superficial Ce3+ species. On the other hand, the high-temperature peak is associated with the reoxidation of the Co and Ce species found in the bulk mixed oxides, indicating the two types of reducibility encountered among the redox species, depending on their position inside the particles. As expected, the oxygen consumption increased with the Co loading, as more redox species are available in the samples for reaction with O2 ( Table 5). Considering that the O2 consumption is split between the two temperature regions, it can be observed that the highest contribution is due to the reoxidation at lower temperatures, indicating the presence of more active superficial species in the catalysts. Moreover, the reoxidation degrees of the Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxides were calculated to evaluate the redox properties of the catalysts and were included in Table 5. The results revealed the highest reoxidation percentage of 100 % for the Co(40)CeMgAlO sample, showcasing the high oxygen mobility in the lattice and its excellent redox behavior, thus emphasizing its potential in combustion reactions. 3.2 Catalytic properties Combustion reactions using methane as a model molecule were carried out on the Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxides to evaluate their catalytic ability in a temperature range limited to a value lower than their calcination temperature. The conversion – reaction temperature plots for the methane combustion over the Co(x)CeMgAlO catalysts were depicted in Fig. 7. All the tested mixed oxides exhibited a 100 % selectivity towards CO2, irrespective of their cobalt loading, as shown by the chromatograms of the reaction mixture resulted after the catalytic combustion at two different temperatures, i.e., 500 and 600 °C, over the Co(7)-, Co(21)- and Co(40)CeMgAlO mixed oxide catalysts, depicted in Fig. S11. This fact reveals their high potential as catalysts for the complete oxidation reactions. The T10, T50 and T90 temperatures, corresponding to 10 %, 50 % and 90 % methane conversion, respectively, and the intrinsic and specific activities at 450 and 500 °C are listed in Table 6. It can be observed that the Co(40)CeMgAlO system presents the highest catalytic activity in methane total oxidation in the catalyst series, as it has the lowest conversion temperatures and it is the only material able to achieve total conversion of methane. In terms of T10, the catalytic activity of this series follows the order: Co(40) > Co(50) > Co(30) > Co(21) > Co(14) > Co(7) > CeMgAlO. These results suggest that a maximum in activity is achieved among the Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxides, dependent on the Co content. Taking into account the H2 consumption in the low temperature region from the TPR measurements, it can be observed that the Co-containing catalysts are reduced at lower temperatures with higher H2 amounts compared to the CeMgAlO sample, explaining their increased activity at temperatures lower than 600 °C. However, at high temperatures some of the Co-containing catalysts became less active than the Co-free catalyst likely due to increased mass transfer limitations. The intrinsic and specific activities of the Co-containing catalysts in the low-temperature range, i.e., at 450 and 500 °C, increase with the Co content, exceeding those of the CeMgAlO support, and reach a maximum for the Co(40) sample (Table 6). Notably, the T50 value of the Co(40)CeMgAlO is ca. 75 °C lower than that of the Co-free catalyst, indicating the enhanced catalytic activity of the mixed oxide system in methane conversion. The Co(40)CeMgAlO mixed oxide, the most active in this series, was compared in Table S3 with other oxide-based catalysts reported in the literature for the total oxidation of methane, including Co-containing and ex-LDH systems. It can be observed that its catalytic performance, in terms of T50, is comparable with other reported results. However, it is significantly lower compared to that of NiCo2O4 spinel catalysts, which are able to completely oxidize methane at temperatures as low as 410 °C [56] and, even, 350 °C [57], depending on the method of their preparation and the reaction conditions used. This suggests that there is still room for improvement of the ex-LDH Co-based mixed oxide catalyst by the addition of Ni or other promoting cations, as already effected in the case of a Cu-based LDH-derived mixed oxide [58]. It is noteworthy that the intrinsic rate of methane conversion over the Co-containing catalysts at both 450 and 500 °C linearly increases with the hydrogen consumption in the H2-TPR experiments reaching a maximum for the Co(40)CeMgAlO system, then it decreases for Co(50)CeMgAlO ( Fig. 8a). The same evolution of the intrinsic reaction rates at the two reaction temperatures considered can be observed when plotted as a function of the total oxygen consumption in the O2-TPO experiments (Fig. S12). These data show that, except for Co(50)CeMgAlO system, the same species involved in the reduction and reoxidation processes are also involved in the catalytic combustion reaction, the amount of the active redox sites increasing with the Co content. This clearly suggests that the total oxidation of methane over the Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxide catalysts takes place via a heterogeneous redox mechanism. In the case of Co(50)CeMgAlO catalyst, not all the reduced and reoxidized species in the H2-TPR and O2-TPO experiments, respectively, are involved in catalysis, but only those located on the surface and subsurface region of the large Co3O4 active phase particles. This suggests that the agglomerated cobalt oxide particles (as shown by SEM analysis) became too large in the Co(50)CeMgAlO system and, hence, not all the reducible Co species are available for catalysis, which explains the observed decline of activity of this catalyst. Notably, the evolution of the specific reaction rates expressed both per unit mass of catalyst (mol g−1 s−1) and per unit mass of cobalt (mol gCo −1 s−1) as a function of the total H2 consumption (Fig. S13a and S14) is similar to that observed for the intrinsic reaction rate in the Co(x)CeMgAlO series. This suggests that the active component is the Co-containing phase, i.e., Co3O4, and that the same fraction of this active phase is exposed, confirming the homogeneous composition of the ex-LDH mixed oxides in line with the EDX elemental mapping images presented in Fig. S6. On the other hand, a good linear correlation between the intrinsic reaction rate at 450 °C and the low-temperature oxygen consumption in O2-TPO experiments can be observed for all the Co-containing catalysts (Fig. 8b). A similar dependence can also be noticed for the specific reaction rate at 450 °C (Fig. S13b). Indeed, the reaction rate increases with the O2 consumption in the Co(x)CeMgAlO catalyst series, with the highest consumed oxygen amount for the Co(40) sample associated with its highest reaction rate. As the low-temperature peak from the O2-TPO measurements appears at temperatures lower than 450 °C, the respective oxygen consumption is ascribed to the active redox sites involved in the methane combustion reaction that occurs at 450 °C for all the Co-containing catalysts. Moreover, the intrinsic methane conversion rate at 450 and 500 °C revealed the same trend as the Co/Ce surface atomic ratio, when plotted as a function of the Co content in the catalyst series, with a maximum of both of them for the Co(40)CeMgAlO system ( Fig. 9). This dependence is another indicative for the superiority of Co(40)CeMgAlO mixed oxide in methane total oxidation, also pointing out the important role of the Co/Ce surface atomic ratio in determining the catalytic activity of the Co(x)CeMgAlO systems. Obviously, a synergistic interaction between the Co and Ce species takes place, being optimal for a certain catalyst composition, which corresponds to the Co(40)CeMgAlO mixed oxide. To avoid the diffusion influences that appear at higher reaction temperatures, only low-temperature conversion data have been used to determine the apparent activation energies (Ea) on the different catalysts. They were calculated from the slope of the linear lnr i versus 103/T plots in Fig. S15 and were tabulated in Table 6. It can be observed that the activation energy decreases with the increase in Co content until 30 at% Co, then it increases for higher Co loading in the mixed oxide catalyst. This variation suggests the change in the nature of the catalytic sites required for the combustion reaction with the Co content in the mixed oxide, in line with a Co-Ce synergistic interaction. Obviously, the activity of the Co(30)CeMgAlO mixed oxide, which has the lowest activation energy, and that of the Co(40)CeMgAlO system, which is the most active in the series, is determined by the interplay between the strength of the active sites and their surface density. Notably, the activation energy values for the most active Co(x)CeMgAlO systems (72–85 kJ mol−1) are comparable to those for other catalysts with similar composition used in methane combustion [24,36,58], and quite close to the value corresponding to a bulk Co3O4 catalyst (78 kJ mol−1) [59]. This clearly indicates that the active phase in the Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxides is the spinel Co3O4 phase. In fact, the Co(x)CeMgAlO systems are complex mixed oxides which include cobalt oxide particles interacting with ceria particles dispersed over a Mg(Al)O periclase-like mixed oxide. Obviously, the ceria particles act as oxygen storage deposits, required during combustion reactions. Further, the effect of GHSV on the catalytic activity was studied for the most active Co(40)CeMgAlO catalyst. As expected, the light-off curves shift toward higher temperatures with the increase in GHSV while the methane concentration was kept constant in the feed gas at 1 vol% ( Fig. 10), the effect being more pronounced for a greater increase of the GHSV. Indeed, it can be seen that the T50 value increases from 528 to 536 and 546 °C when the GHSV has been increased from 16000 to 20,000 and 30,000 h−1, respectively. In general, the LDH-derived catalysts have been reported to display good stability during the methane total combustion [24,32,33]. Nevertheless, the Co(40)CeMgAlO, the most active catalyst in the series, was maintained on stream at 600 °C for ca. 55 h to evaluate its stability. The catalytic activity of the Co(40)CeMgAlO material showed no significant change during the combustion reaction, after the prolonged time on stream, as illustrated in Fig. 11, emphasizing its good stability, at least for the reaction conditions and the reaction time chosen. This is likely due to the Mg(Al)O periclase-like support, which provides more thermal stability in high temperature operating conditions. To evaluate the effect of water vapors on the catalytic performance of the Co(40)CeMgAlO, combustion tests in cycles of dry/humid conditions at 600 °C were performed by adding, with a peristaltic pump, 0.14 mL min−1 of deionized liquid water to the dry mixture, which corresponds to a water vapor content of ca. 40 vol%. The results obtained are shown on Fig. 12. It can be observed that during the first cycle of humid conditions the methane conversion significantly decreased. Obviously, this is the effect of the water vapor itself combined with the increase of the GHSV and the decrease of the methane concentration in the humid reaction mixture. Then, when the catalyst sample was subjected to a methane combustion run in dry conditions, its catalytic activity has only partially recovered. These results clearly indicate the negative effect of water vapors on the performance of the Co(40)CeMgAlO catalyst, which seems to be irreversibly affected. However, after several cycles of dry/humid conditions during the methane combustion the conversion remained relatively stable. To explain the activity loss in the presence of water vapors, the Co(40)CeMgAlO catalyst used during the combustion cycles in dry/humid conditions was characterized by XRD and nitrogen adsorption-desorption. The XRD pattern of this sample is compared to that of the fresh catalyst in Fig. S16. Less intense diffraction lines corresponding to the periclase-like phase and the presence of lines at 11.29, 22.18 and 34.54° 2θ ascribed to a reconstructed LDH phase can be observed in the diffractogram of the used system, suggesting its hydroxylation during the test in humid conditions. Moreover, the cobalt oxide spinel phase increased its crystallite size from 13.9 to ca. 16.7 nm, which indicates an apparent sintering effect of the active phase with consequences on the catalytic activity recovery. Although the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of the used and fresh samples are similar (Fig. S17a), the surface area of the used catalyst increased and its pore volume decreased (Table 1). Also, a change from unimodal pores with maxima 17.9 nm for the fresh sample to narrower bimodal pores with maxima at 3.7 and 12.4 nm for the used catalyst was noticed (Fig. S17b), which is likely due to the LDH reconstruction during the reaction in humid conditions. All these structural and textural changes explain the activity loss observed in the presence of water vapors. 4 Conclusion A series of Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxides with fixed Ce content of 10 at% with respect to cations and Mg/Al mol ratio of 3, but with different cobalt loadings x in the range from 7 to 50 at%, was prepared by calcination at 750 °C of LDH precursors. They consist of periclase-like Mg(Al)O phase, CeO2 fluorite phase and Co3O4 spinel crystallites, the latter being well defined at higher Co loadings. The active phase is cobalt oxide which interacts with ceria, the latter acting as oxygen storage deposits. The Co content strongly influences the physicochemical characteristics of the mixed oxide, including its redox properties, and, hence, its catalytic behavior. The redox behavior and the Co/Ce surface atomic ratio were shown to be important factors determining the catalytic activity of the Co(x)CeMgAlO catalysts. Having the highest Co/Ce surface atomic ratio and the best redox properties, the Co(40)CeMgAlO mixed oxide exhibited the highest catalytic activity for the total oxidation of methane in this series, with a T50 value of 528 °C. The Co(40)CeMgAlO system showed a good stability on stream at high temperature, likely provided by the Mg(Al)O periclase-like support. However, the presence of water vapors in the feed has a negative effect on the catalytic performance, which is only partially recovered in dry conditions, due to textural and structural changes of the catalytic material. coredata.dc:description: Several Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxides with different cobalt contents x between 7 and 50 at% with respect to cations, but with fixed 10 at% Ce and Mg/Al atomic ratio of 3, were obtained by the calcination of layered double hydroxide (LDH) precursors at 750 °C. The mixed oxide catalysts were characterized by XRD, nitrogen adsorption, DRIFT, DR-UV-Vis, SEM-EDX, including elemental mapping, XPS, H2-TPR and O2-TPO techniques. XRD analysis indicated the coexistence of Co3O4 crystallites with periclase-like and ceria phases, distributed homogeneously as shown by EDX measurements. The surface composition determined by XPS and the redox properties studied by H2-TPR and O2-TPO were shown to be key factors controlling the catalytic behavior of the investigated materials. Their catalytic performance was evaluated in the total oxidation of methane, used as a volatile organic compound (VOC) model molecule. Co(40)CeMgAlO mixed oxide showed the highest catalytic activity for methane combustion with a T50 of 528 °C, associated with its greatest Co/Ce surface atomic ratio and the best redox properties in the Co(x)CeMgAlO series. In addition, the influence of the contact time on the catalytic activity of the Co(40)CeMgAlO mixed oxide has been examined and its good stability was evidenced from combustion tests with prolonged time on stream. Nevertheless, the addition of water vapors to the reaction mixture induces textural and structural changes of the mixed oxide with negative consequences on its performance.
coredata.dc:title: Multicationic LDH-derived Co(x)CeMgAlO mixed oxide catalysts for the total oxidation of methane
